Award.AwardTitle: BIGDATA: Mid-Scale: DA: Distribution-based machine learning for high dimensional datasets

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration:
Many applications call for representation and analysis of 'distributional' data sets where each data point is a collection of samples from a high dimensional distribution (as opposed to valuations of a typically vector valued random variable). In this setting, each data point can be modeled by a collection of distributions, one for each measured attribute. A concrete example of distributional data arises in the context of brain connectivity mapping. The human brain contains around a hundred billion neurons with several hundred trillion physical connections. Neuroimaging approaches, like Diffusion Spectrum Imaging attempt to visualize the underlying anatomical architecture of neural pathways by creating 3D probability distributions of water diffusion along nerve fiber bundles, called orientation distribution functions.

The project aims to develop new statistical and algorithmic approaches to natural generalizations of a class of standard machine learning problems (where multi-dimensional vector valued data points are replaced by distributions), including techniques for measuring distances and inner products between distributional data points, estimating variants of entropy, mutual information, conditional mutual information, clustering distributional data, constructing low-dimensional embeddings of distributional data, and learning classifiers and function approximators from distributional data. The resulting methods will be evaluated on large diffusion scan imaging data sets (where the data point for each patient consists of 500,000 distributions).

The novel machine learning approaches for descriptive and predictive modeling of distributional data resulting from this project are expected to benefit other scientific fields where data points can be naturally modeled by sets of distributions, which is a common situation in physics, psychology, economics, epidemiology, medicine, and social network-analysis. New distributional data set to be obtained at CMU to augment the data available from NTU are likely to allow other research groups to engage in research on big data analytics from distributional data. Release of open source software, video tutorials, research-training of graduate students contribute to the broader impacts of the project. Additional information about the project can be found at: http://www.autonlab.org/autonweb/20928.html.

POR.DRECONTENT:
A major goal of this project was to develop novel tools for working with complex diffusion MRI data, conisting of hundreds of thousdands of samples of the anatomical connections in the human brain modeled as 3 dimensional functions of water diffusion patterns. On the application side of the project, we used a hybrid of methods for working with ultra-high dimensional data sets to show how the macroscopic white matter pathways in the brain reflect individual identity. We called this method "local connectome fingerprinting". This process is shown in the attached figure.

Our results found that the human white matter pathways are highly unique to an individual. Out of over 17,000 tests, our approach never misclassified whether two scans belonged to the same individual. In addition, we found a 12% similarity in global white matter architecture between genetically identical individuals (i.e., monozygotic twins) and that within the same person, the global white matter architecture changes at a rate of ~12% every 100 days. Thus the tools developed as part of this project greatly expanded the analytical tractability of diffusion MRI data and allowed us to assess how experience and genetics contribute to global structural connectivity patterns in the human brain.

This work was peer reviewed and published the journal PLoS Computational Biology. Quantifying Differences and Similarities in Whole-Brain White Matter Architecture Using Local Connectome Fingerprints Yeh FC, Vettel JM, Singh A, Poczos B, Grafton ST, et al. (2016) Quantifying Differences and Similarities in Whole-Brain White Matter Architecture Using Local Connectome Fingerprints. PLOS Computational Biology 12(11): e1005203. doi: 10.1371/journal.pcbi.1005203

Addendum # 1

Modern datasets are not only getting larger (i.e., more data points) but they are also getting much more complex (i.e., increased interdependence and uncertainty amongst the variables describing the data). In this project, we proposed a new approach to view datapoints in such datasets as high-dimensional probabilistic distributions, rather than scalars or vectors and develop novel analytical tools for learning from such distributional datasets. As a concrete example of this, modern human brain imaging can create 3D probabilistic representations of white matter structure (i.e., axons) throughout the brain. This produces datasets with hundreds of thousands or millions of distributions for every subject and dozens or hundreds of subjects per experiment. Yet modern neuroimaging tools are limited in their ability to describe relational patterns between these 3D distributions because of the immense size and complexity of these datasets. In this project, we developed scalable and principled machine learning approaches to analyzing datasets consisting of large, high-dimensional distributions of data. Specifically, we developed methods and theory for 1) prediction using distributions as inputs in high-dimensions, 2) estimating functionals of distributions such as entropy, divergence and mutual information; 3) testing samples from distributions in high dimensions to distinguish two distributions or test their independence; and 4) active learning of distributions. This results and findings are described in 16 publications in prominent machine learning venues including ICML, NIPS, AISTATS, AAAI, ISIT, Journal of Machine Learning Research and several publications in neuroscience venues including Frontiers in Neuroscience, PLoS Computational Biology and NeuroImage. 

A major applied goal of this project was to develop novel tools for working with complex diffusion MRI data, consisting of hundreds of thousands of samples of the anatomical connections in the human brain modeled as 3 dimensional functions of water diffusion patterns. On the application side of the project, we used a hybrid of methods for working with ultra-high dimensional data sets to show how the macroscopic white matter pathways in the brain reflect individual identity. We called this method "local connectome fingerprinting". This process is shown in the attached figure. Our results found that the human white matter pathways are highly unique to an individual. Out of over 17,000 tests, our approach never misclassified whether two scans belonged to the same individual. In addition, we found a 12% similarity in global white matter architecture between genetically identical individuals (i.e., monozygotic twins) and that within the same person, the global white matter architecture changes at a rate of ~12% every 100 days. Thus the tools developed as part of this project greatly expanded the analytical tractability of diffusion MRI data and allowed us to assess how experience and genetics contribute to global structural connectivity patterns in the human brain.

This project provided interdisciplinary training on machine learning for modern datasets to postdoc fellows, graduate (PhD and Masters) students as well as undergraduates. The methods and data from this project were also used for a Neurohackathon event and an outreach event OurCS at Carnegie Mellon University encouraging female undergraduates to pursue research in computer science.
